item.a: call something out /kˈɔːl sˈʌmθɪŋ ˈaʊt/ Arne Carlson did what governors do in an emergency - called out the National Guard.

item.q: (phrase) to try to find something
item.a: cast about /cast about/ I cast about for a place to live.

item.q: (phrase) to supply someone for a short time with something that is lacking
item.a: tide someone over /tˈaɪd sˈʌmwɒn ˈəʊvə/ Can you lend me some money to tide me over till next month? | I gave her a hundred pounds to tide her over till she gets paid.

item.q: (phrase) to take care of a child until it is an adult
item.a: bring someone up She brought up four children.

item.q: (phrase) to produce something and sell it
item.a: bring something out /bɹˈɪŋ sˈʌmθɪŋ ˈaʊt/ He's now brought out a book.

item.q: (phrase) When the plane lands, we can say it...?
item.a: touch down /tˈʌtʃ dˈaʊn/ The spacecraft touched down on schedule.

item.q: (phrase) to officially show that you have arrived at a place by signing a book or form
item.a: sign in I singed in and went straight to my room.

item.q: (phrase) to wait patiently for someone to finish doing something
item.a: bear with someone Bear with me, Frank, just let me explain.

item.q: (phrase) to write something down quickly
item.a: jot something down /dʒˈɑːt sˈʌmθɪŋ dˈaʊn/ David jotted down the address on a notepad.

item.q: (phrase) To receive money, property, or a title as a result of the death of a relative
item.a: come into something /kˈʌm ˌɪntʊ sˈʌmθɪŋ/ She came into a bit of money when her grandfather died. | She came into a bit of money when her grandfather died.

item.q: (phrase) to move away from someone or something, often because you are frightened
item.a: back away James stood up, but the girl backed away.

item.q: (phrase) to get rid of someone or something
item.a: cast someone or something aside /kˈast • ɐsˈaɪd/ In America we seem to cast aside our old people.

item.q: (phrase) to form a total
item.a: add up to something Altogether, the three bills add up to $2.456.

item.q: (phrase) If an aircraft, bird, or insect do this, it leaves the ground and begins to flyimgs/take.off.plane.jpeg
item.a: take off /tˈeɪk ˈɒf/ The plane took off at 8.30 a.m.

item.q: (phrase) to look for someone or something, especially for a long time until you find him, her, or it
item.a: seek sb/sth out /sˈiːk ˈaʊt/ While he was at the library, Steve decided to seek out some information on the history of the area.

item.q: (phrase) to blow at a flame so that it stops burning
item.a: blow something out I blew out the candle.

item.q: (phrase) to destroy a building by fire, or to be destroyed in this way
item.a: burn down or burn something down The old prison had been burned down one night. | Her house burned down with all her personal possessions in it.

item.q: (phrase) to get bigger so that a piece of clothing fits properly
item.a: grow into something /ɡɹˈəʊ ˌɪntʊ sˈʌmθɪŋ/ It's a bit big, but she'll soon grow into it. | Never buy a bike that’s too big and expect your child to grow into it.

item.q: (phrasal) to succeed in avoiding punishment for something
item.a: get away with something /ɡɛt ɐwˈeɪ wɪð sˈʌmθɪŋ/ If I thought I could get away with it, I wouldn't pay my taxes at all. | By jumping over the barriers, he got away without paying for a ticket. | Everyone thinks he's guilty of the robbery, but it looks like he's going to get away with it.

item.q: (phrase) to end a relationship
item.a: break up or break up with someone /bɹˈeɪk ˌʌp wɪð sˈʌmwɒn/ My girlfriend has broken up with me. | We broke up last year.

item.q: (phrase) to ​continue doing something, or to ​cause something to ​continue
item.a: carry on /kˈaɹi ˈɒn/ Carry on the good ​work! | Sorry to ​interrupt, ​please ​carry on (with what you were saying). | You just have to ​carry on as if nothing's ​happened. | Let's ​carry on this ​discussion at some other ​time.

item.q: (phrasal) to make something ​seem less ​important or less ​bad than it really is
item.a: play something down /plˈeɪ sˈʌmθɪŋ dˈaʊn/ Military ​spokespeople ​tried to ​play down the ​seriousness of the ​disaster.

item.q: (phrasal) 1) to practice a performance or a series of actions 2) to read or mention all the items on a list quickly
item.a: run through something /ɹˈʌn θɹuː sˈʌmθɪŋ/ Doug listened while I ran through the routine again. | I ran through the options with him.

item.q: (phrase) to explain something or give the reason for it
item.a: account for something How do you account for the differences in the two figures?

item.q: (phrase) to speak to someone in an angry or serious way because they have done something wrong
item.a: tell someone off He never listened to us when we told him off.

item.q: (phrase) to hit or kick someone many times
item.a: beat someone up I was beaten up and lost a lot of blood.

item.q: (phrase) to not have the chance to take part in something
item.a: miss out on something You missed out on all the fun yesterday.

item.q: (phrase) to blame yourself for something bad that has happend (informal)
item.a: beat yourself up /bˈiːt jɔːsˈɛlf ˈʌp/ Tell them you don't want to do it any more. Don't beat yourself up about it.

item.q: (phrase) to become less upset or excited
item.a: calm down /kˈɑːm dˈaʊn/ Calm down and listen to me.

item.q: (phrase) to stop working OR to start crying
item.a: break down /bɹˈeɪk dˈaʊn/ Their car broke down. | I broke down and cried.

item.q: (phrase) to become unconscious for a short time
item.a: black out For a moment he thought he was going to black out.

item.q: (phrase) to grow or increase very quickly
item.a: shoot up /ʃˈuːt ˈʌp/ Sales have shot up by 9%.

item.q: (phrase) 1. to change position to a better, higher, or more advantageous one. 2. to bring closer to the present time
item.a: move up or move something up The price of gold moved up for the third day in a row. | Qantas has moved up delivery of eight of its 50 orders Boeing 787 Dreamliners by around two years.

item.q: (phrase) to get into a building by force
item.a: break in The robbers broke in and stole $8.000.

item.q: (phrase) to have a romantic relationship with someone
item.a: go out with someone I've been going out with my girlfriend for three months.

item.q: (phrase) 1. to leave your home to do something enjoyable 2. to stop shining or burning
item.a: go out I'm going out tonight. | The fire went out and the room became cold.

item.q: (phrase) to remove one part of a thing from the rest of it by breaking it
item.a: break something off /bɹˈeɪk sˈʌmθɪŋ ˈɒf/ Grace broke off a large piece of bread.

item.q: (phrase) to introduce a subject into a discussion or conversation
item.a: bring something up Why are you bringing it up now?

item.q: (phrase) to cancel an event that has been planned
item.a: call something off /kˈɔːl sˈʌmθɪŋ ˈɒf/ He called off the trip.

item.q: (phrasal) to have no more of something left
item.a: run out of something We ran out of milk this morning.

item.q: (phrase) if a computer does it, or if you do it, it starts working so that you can use it.
item.a: boot up or boot something up Go over to your computer and boot it up. | He left the machine to boot up while he looked around.

item.q: (phrasal) to ​hit and ​drive over someone or something with a ​vehicle
item.a: run someone over /ɹˈʌn sˈʌmwɒn ˈəʊvə/ A police car ran him over.

item.q: (phrase) to eat in a restaurant
item.a: eat out /ˈiːt ˈaʊt/ When I lived in Spain, I used to eat out all the time. | I'm not implying anything about your cooking, but could we eat out tonight? | You can tell from his empty unused kitchen that he tends to eat out a lot.

item.q: (phrase) to reach someone in front of you by walking faster than them OR to reach the same level as someone else
(phrase) to return something
item.a: bring something back Could you please bring back those books that I lent you?

item.q: (phrase) to disappoint someone, usually by not doing something that you said you would do
item.a: let someone down Don't worry, Robert, I won't let you down.

item.q: (phrase) to stop burning because there is no more fuel
item.a: burn out /bˈɜːn ˈaʊt/ Most of the fires are expected to burn out by the weekend.

item.q: (phrasal) to meet someone unexpectedly
item.a: run into someone He ran into William in the supermarket.

item.q: (phrase) to take some air into your lungs
item.a: breathe in Now breathe in through your nose.

item.q: (phrase) to cover part of the body with clothes, shoes, make-up, or something similar
item.a: put sth on Put your shoes on - we're going out. | He put on his jacket. | She puts face cream on every night.

item.q: (phrase) to telephone someone in return for a call they made to you
item.a: call someone back I'll call you back.

item.q: (phrase) to show that something is true OR to make a copy of a computer file so that you can use it if the original file is lost
item.a: back something up /bˈak sˈʌmθɪŋ ˈʌp/ He didn't have any proof to back up his story. | Make sure you back up your files every day.

item.q: (phrase) to wait patiently for someone to finish doing something
item.a: bear with someone Bear with me, Frank, just let me explain.

item.q: (n) either of two ​symbols put around a word, phrase, or ​sentence in a ​piece of writing to show that what is between them should be ​considered as ​separate from the ​main ​partimgs/bracket.235234.png
item.a: bracket /ˈbræk.ɪt/ Biographical ​information is ​included in brackets. | You should ​include the ​date of ​publication in round brackets after the ​title.snds/ukboyfr015.mp3

item.q: (n) the ​symbol : used in writing, ​especially to ​introduce a ​list of things or a ​sentence or phrase taken from ​somewhere ​else
(n) the ​character _ on a ​computer ​keyboard, used to ​draw a ​line under a ​letter or word, and also used in ​file ​names where a ​space is not ​allowed
(n) the ​symbols ( ) that are put around a word, phrase, or ​sentence in a ​piece of writing to show that what is inside them should be ​considered as ​separate from the ​main ​part
item.a: parentheses /pəˈren.θə.siːz/ The ​students' first ​names are ​shown in parentheses, like this: Baker (Tina).snds/cald4uk1168.mp3

item.q: (n) Also known as inverted commas – simply separate the words someone in a sentence actually says from the rest of the sentence. These words are called direct speech.
item.a: Speech marks /spˈiːtʃ mˈɑːks/ "I’ll be back home soon," Jim shouted to his mum.

item.q: (n) the ​symbol – used to ​separate ​parts of a ​sentence
(n) the ​symbol ! written ​immediately after an ​exclamation
item.a: exclamation mark /ek.skləˈmeɪ.ʃən ˌmɑːk/ She uses a lot of ​exclamation ​marks in her ​emails. | The ​letter was peppered with ​exclamation ​marks.

item.q: (n) the ​symbol ? used in writing at the end of a phrase or ​sentence to show that it is a ​question
item.a: question mark /ˈkwes.tʃən ˌmɑːk/ Was there a ​question ​mark at the end of the ​sentence? | Where is the ​question ​mark on this ​keyboard?

item.q: (n) the ​symbol ; used in writing between two ​parts of a ​sentence, usually when each of the two ​parts could ​form ​grammatical ​sentences on ​their own. A semicolon can also ​separate the things in a ​list.
the @ ​symbol that ​joins the ​name of a ​person or a ​department in an ​organization to a ​domain ​name to make an ​email ​address
(n) three ​dots in a ​printed ​text that show where one or more words have been ​intentionally ​left out

(n) the ​symbol ’ used in writing to show when a ​letter or a ​number has been ​left out, as in I'm (= I am) or '85 (= 1985), or that is used before or after s to show ​possession, as in Helen's ​house or ​babies' ​hands
item.a: apostrophe /əˈpɒs.trə.fi/ "It's" with an apostrophe ​means "it is" or "it has".snds/ukapolo009.mp3

item.q: (n) the ​symbol -, used to ​join two words together, or to show that a word has been ​divided into two ​parts at the end of one ​line and the ​beginning of the next
(n) the ​symbol , used in writing to ​separate ​parts of a ​sentence ​showing a ​slight ​pause, or to ​separate the ​single things in a ​list
item.a: comma /ˈkɒm.ə/ Put a comma after the ​clause. | We usually put a comma after thousands in ​numbers. | Should I put a comma before the 'and'?snds/ukcombi028.mp3

item.q: (n) the ​symbol / used in writing to ​separate ​letters, ​numbers, or words also oblique (stroke)
item.a: slash /slæʃ/ You often write a slash between ​alternatives, for ​example, "and/or".snds/uksland017.mp3

item.q: (n) the ​symbol . used in writing at the end of a ​sentence or at the end of the ​short ​form of a word
item.a: full stop /ˌfʊl ˈstɒp/ He ​keeps ​missing the full stop ​offs the ​ends of his ​sentences. | Make ​sure you put a full stop at the end of every ​sentence.
